article_title: Federal Health Insurer Network Ratings Are Bizarre And Inconsistent

article_metadata.description: The Obama administration recently detailed its plan to rate the breadth of health insurer networks that are made available on healthcare.gov. It's a very peculiar method. It's inconsistent with the method the administration already uses to determine whether networks are adequate and different from what the Obama administration is strongly suggesting that states do for those states running their own exchanges. Moreover, the metric chosen in the recent regulation -- relative provider ratios -- has at least nine significant flaws. Admittedly, rating networks is a hard problem. But, particularly given that the Obama administration's statutory authority to go beyond simple determinations of network adequacy is dubious, perhaps it would be better off not trying. It might provide more service my using its authority just to collect a lot of potentially relevant raw data from insurers and let private entities compete in developing meaningful rating systems. This alternative method works tolerably well in the world of commercial products and services (Yelp, Amazon), and it might well work better than heavy-handed, elaborate federal regulation.
article_metadata.author: The Apothecary
